title: How to Demineralize a Dishwasher

steps.headline: Remove the dishes from the dishwasher.
steps.description: Take out any dishes or utensils before you begin demineralization. Anything inside the dishwasher will get in the way of the vinegar spreading. Vinegar is also acidic and may damage plastic.

steps.headline: Pour white vinegar into a dishwasher-safe glass.
steps.description: Fill the glass with a cup (240 mL) of white vinegar. Some cleaning guides recommend as much as two cups (480 mL) of vinegar. While you can use the extra vinegar, especially if you have a tall or wide dishwasher, minimize the amount of vinegar used as much as possible. Baking soda can be used as an alternative to vinegar. Sprinkle a cup of it on the bottom of the machine. Unsweetened lemonade mix is also an alternative. Pour a packet of it into the soap dispenser. Don’t use flavored varieties or else you’ll stain the machine. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				You can also pour the vinegar directly into the dishwasher. Chris Willatt, the owner of Alpine Maids, says: "Fill the basin up with about 1/4 in (6 mm) of vinegar, then run a cycle. The vinegar will help dissolve the minerals and clean out the filter."

steps.headline: Place the cup in the top rack.
steps.description: The cup filled with vinegar should be the only object in the dishwasher. Once you are sure it is secure, close the door.

steps.headline: Run the machine through a hot water cycle.
steps.description: Make sure the door is sealed and that the washer doesn’t have open vents, or else you’ll breathe in vinegar fumes. Set the machine to the hottest water setting. Let it go through a short wash cycle.

steps.headline: Run another short hot water cycle with baking soda.
steps.description: The vinegar will leave a potent smell. You can simply leave the door open overnight to get rid of it. A quicker option is to sprinkle a cup (240 mL) of baking soda over the floor of the washer. Run another wash cycle with hot water. The dishwasher should look nice and clean afterwards.

steps.headline: Remove all dishes and utensils.
steps.description: Clear out the dishwasher. Anything left inside it could be damaged during treatment.

steps.headline: Get a stain remover for appliances.
steps.description: Find stain removing products such as Bar Keeper’s Friend and Lime-A-Way. They’ll be near the laundry aisle in general stores and home improvement stores. Make sure they’re for use on appliances. Reddish stains or a dulled interior are due to rust. White stains are from limescale buildup.

steps.headline: Place the product in the soap dispenser.
steps.description: Follow the directions on the label. Fill the soap dispenser with the product. Follow up by sprinkling some of it on the floor of the washer.

steps.headline: Run the dishwasher through a cleaning cycle.
steps.description: Set the dishwasher for a normal cycle unless the instructions on the product say otherwise. Now wait for it to finish. The machine should look much better.

steps.headline: Install a purification and filtration system.
steps.description: These stains will continue to form as long as you have hard water. A purification and filtration system is expensive but will filter out the iron and calcium that causes these stains. Replacing rusty pipes also stops rust stains from forming. Depending on your situation, this may not be an option.

steps.headline: Take out the racks and utensil holders.
steps.description: Remove anything inside the machine, if possible. This will help you clean off the dishwasher’s accessories as well as reach the inside of the machine.

steps.headline: Mix water and soap.
steps.description: Any dish detergent or appliance cleaner will do. Add a few drops of the cleaner to some water, enough to get it soapy. The soapy water can help you remove food and other stains that have begun to set. A mildly abrasive cleaner like Soft Scrub can be used for tough grime.

steps.headline: Wipe down the sides of the dishwasher with a sponge.
steps.description: You can use paper towels to pick up large amounts of grime first. Afterwards, dip a sponge into the soapy water and use it to scrub out debris. An old toothbrush will help you get into smaller areas, such as the edges of the door.

steps.headline: Clear off the drain with paper towels.
steps.description: Most debris settles around the drain, which is often on the floor of the dishwasher. Pick it all up with paper towels. Make sure the drain is clear and that water passes through it. Improper drainage will damage the machine and cause more mineralization. For a clogged dishwasher, combine one tablespoon baking soda and two tablespoons vinegar. Pour it down the drain and leave it for about fifteen minutes. Follow it with a pot of boiling water.

steps.headline: Scrub the spray arm with a soft brush.
steps.description: The spray arm is the part of the dishwasher that looks like a propeller blade with holes. If you have one, clean it with the soapy water. Rub it first using the sponge, paper towels, or a damp rag. Follow up with a soft brush or toothpick to clear out the holes.

steps.headline: Wash the filter system with soap and water.
steps.description: Newer machines have filters that catch debris. The filter will be on the floor of the machine near the spray arm. Unscrew the filter system and pull it out. Usually it consists of several connected parts. Rinse them off with your sponge dipped in the soapy water. A small brush will also help you remove smaller particles from the filter.

steps.headline: Wipe off the racks and utensil holders.
steps.description: Give the accessories a thorough wipedown to remove debris. Use paper towels or your sponge dipped in the soapy water. When you’re finished, reassemble the inside of the dishwasher.

text: Using Vinegar and Baking Soda Remove the dishes from the dishwasher. Take out any dishes or utensils before you begin demineralization. Anything inside the dishwasher will get in the way of the vinegar spreading. Vinegar is also acidic and may damage plastic. Pour white vinegar into a dishwasher-safe glass. Fill the glass with a cup (240 mL) of white vinegar. Some cleaning guides recommend as much as two cups (480 mL) of vinegar. While you can use the extra vinegar, especially if you have a tall or wide dishwasher, minimize the amount of vinegar used as much as possible. Baking soda can be used as an alternative to vinegar. Sprinkle a cup of it on the bottom of the machine. Unsweetened lemonade mix is also an alternative. Pour a packet of it into the soap dispenser. Don’t use flavored varieties or else you’ll stain the machine. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				You can also pour the vinegar directly into the dishwasher. Chris Willatt, the owner of Alpine Maids, says: "Fill the basin up with about 1/4 in (6 mm) of vinegar, then run a cycle. The vinegar will help dissolve the minerals and clean out the filter." Place the cup in the top rack. The cup filled with vinegar should be the only object in the dishwasher. Once you are sure it is secure, close the door. Run the machine through a hot water cycle. Make sure the door is sealed and that the washer doesn’t have open vents, or else you’ll breathe in vinegar fumes. Set the machine to the hottest water setting. Let it go through a short wash cycle. Run another short hot water cycle with baking soda. The vinegar will leave a potent smell. You can simply leave the door open overnight to get rid of it. A quicker option is to sprinkle a cup (240 mL) of baking soda over the floor of the washer. Run another wash cycle with hot water. The dishwasher should look nice and clean afterwards. Removing Stubborn Mineral Stains Remove all dishes and utensils. Clear out the dishwasher. Anything left inside it could be damaged during treatment. Get a stain remover for appliances. Find stain removing products such as Bar Keeper’s Friend and Lime-A-Way. They’ll be near the laundry aisle in general stores and home improvement stores. Make sure they’re for use on appliances. Reddish stains or a dulled interior are due to rust. White stains are from limescale buildup. Place the product in the soap dispenser. Follow the directions on the label. Fill the soap dispenser with the product. Follow up by sprinkling some of it on the floor of the washer. Run the dishwasher through a cleaning cycle. Set the dishwasher for a normal cycle unless the instructions on the product say otherwise. Now wait for it to finish. The machine should look much better. Install a purification and filtration system. These stains will continue to form as long as you have hard water. A purification and filtration system is expensive but will filter out the iron and calcium that causes these stains. Replacing rusty pipes also stops rust stains from forming. Depending on your situation, this may not be an option. Maintaining the Dishwasher Take out the racks and utensil holders. Remove anything inside the machine, if possible. This will help you clean off the dishwasher’s accessories as well as reach the inside of the machine. Mix water and soap. Any dish detergent or appliance cleaner will do. Add a few drops of the cleaner to some water, enough to get it soapy. The soapy water can help you remove food and other stains that have begun to set. A mildly abrasive cleaner like Soft Scrub can be used for tough grime. Wipe down the sides of the dishwasher with a sponge. You can use paper towels to pick up large amounts of grime first. Afterwards, dip a sponge into the soapy water and use it to scrub out debris. An old toothbrush will help you get into smaller areas, such as the edges of the door. Clear off the drain with paper towels. Most debris settles around the drain, which is often on the floor of the dishwasher. Pick it all up with paper towels. Make sure the drain is clear and that water passes through it. Improper drainage will damage the machine and cause more mineralization. For a clogged dishwasher, combine one tablespoon baking soda and two tablespoons vinegar. Pour it down the drain and leave it for about fifteen minutes. Follow it with a pot of boiling water. Scrub the spray arm with a soft brush. The spray arm is the part of the dishwasher that looks like a propeller blade with holes. If you have one, clean it with the soapy water. Rub it first using the sponge, paper towels, or a damp rag. Follow up with a soft brush or toothpick to clear out the holes. Wash the filter system with soap and water. Newer machines have filters that catch debris. The filter will be on the floor of the machine near the spray arm. Unscrew the filter system and pull it out. Usually it consists of several connected parts. Rinse them off with your sponge dipped in the soapy water. A small brush will also help you remove smaller particles from the filter. Wipe off the racks and utensil holders. Give the accessories a thorough wipedown to remove debris. Use paper towels or your sponge dipped in the soapy water. When you’re finished, reassemble the inside of the dishwasher.

tyn_section: Soft scrub brush or old toothbrush
